node.text: Nodes can be connected to one another using one of the various types of connections. The two main divisions of nodes are DNA nodes and Species nodes.
Molecular species that diffuse through the cell, such as proteins, RNA, or metabolites.
Metabolites, ions, and other small molecules
Phosphates
Chain of amino acids.
proteins that bind to a regulatory site and influence the activity of the downstream promoter.
Receptors usually have a binding domain and can be localized on the plasma membrane.
Molecules that are used as indicators, such as fluorescent molecules.
RNA molecules
DNA nodes represent components that belong on a DNA strand, such as promoter, genes, etc.
A DNA sequence that encodes for a protein or RNA product.
A complete protein coding region contains a promoter, an RBS, a protein-coding sequence, and transcriptional terminator
Represents a node that can be bound by a Species and usually regulates a gene.
RNA Polymerase binding site; may or may not include the operator sites, depending on the model
A complete protein coding region contains a promoter, an RBS, a protein-coding sequence, and transcriptional terminator
Transcription factor binding site
Ribosome binding site
Transcriptional terminator
A region where the contained species are localized
A module is a network that can contain interfaces and can be connected to other modules.
This item can be used to represent multiple things such as degradation, dilution, or even an alternative transcriptional terminator.
